docs.lead_paragraph: IN this season of giving, the most precious gift you could give might be a pint of blood. Every year at this time, supplies of donated blood drop to a dangerous low, often forcing communities to halt elective operations temporarily so that enough blood is available to meet emergency needs. The combined rush of holiday preparations, vacations, influenza outbreaks, bad weather and business closings can result in a rapid dwindling of blood supplies, sometimes to less than a day's worth in inventory in an area. One patient with a bleeding ulcer could quickly exhaust the supply of a large hospital. A major accident, such as a plane crash, could easily wipe out a region's entire stockpile and still not be enough. A similar problem occurs annually during the summer months, the peak vacation season.

headline.main: DONATED BLOOD SUPPLIES AREN'T MEETING NEEDS

docs.lead_paragraph: DEFECTIVE viruses that play strange and prolonged hide-and-seek games within the body are leading scientists to new concepts of chronic disease and new potential strategies for treating and preventing infection. Furthermore, the circumstances in which viruses go underground, so to speak, are teaching specialists much about the nature, habits and evolution of these tiny infectious particles.

headline.main: VIRUSES LURKING IN CELLS SUSPECTED AS CAUSE OF A HOST OF DISEASES
